about: Perceptions of politics of southern people.
Insinuations while listening to speech, assumptions based on accent, gender, assertion and ethnicity

I think this experiment was trying to evaluate people's first impressions about other people and their political views, confidence in their beliefs, intellect, personality traits, and so on, based on accent, appearance, number of friends, the viewpoints they espouse, and the phrasing of their viewpoints, or something similar.
comments: I made a conscious effort to not automatically stereotype Southerners as being innately stupid or ignorant, even if I don't agree with extreme conservative views. I also believe that first impressions of people should be significantly subject to revision after further interactions, and it often takes time before really getting to know someone. I try not to form conclusive opinions about people with limited context.
otherParty: I was a liberal up until mid-2016 when I became completely disillusioned with politics. I've always been fairly anti-establishment and at this point, I believe that it's highly likely that anybody who reaches a high level of power within our political systems has taken on at least a few sociopathic traits and behaviors, because our systems unfortunately tend to reward self-interested actions. I have very little faith in politics at this point and I just see it as a somewhat necessary evil. I've resigned myself to let other people fight it out, but I still try and live in a way that supports positive changes in society in terms of interpersonal empathy.
whichAccent: I'm not sure. I have a sort of distinctive and raspy voice that people often comment on. People tend to assume I'm from California and sometimes joke about my accent sounding sort of like a surfer or a valley boy. I actually only spent 3 years in California in my early 20's, and mostly grew up in the Metro Boston area, but I don't have a Boston accent. Some people may assume that I have a sort of SoCal accent because I have an 'alternative' aesthetic (long hair, piercings, tattoos) and I spent a lot of time immersed in SoCal punk-influenced culture growing up, despite not growing up there. I guess my accent is closest to that, but one time, I've also heard someone strangely say that my accent sounded slightly Irish (never heard that anywhere else), maybe because I grew up around a lot of Irish people. I also once heard someone say that I had a bit of an Australian accent, which was very strange but funny to me.

comments: I almost think one should skip the profile pictures, because they don't match up with the voices. Are there any other stock photos available for research? For a second, I wanted to include the look of the person. But then I thought not to and went with the best info available, the demographics, what was said and their voice. I listen to different people from almost all over the world in my job. So it's kind of a work hobby to listen to people's tones, meanings, accents and influences on their use of language. The whole voice is very essential. I appreciate your study, thank you!

about: if we think we will know what political party someone follows if they are southern.
comments: I am originally from VA, however, my accent varies depending on who it is I am spending the most time with at the moment. When I am with my sister and her friend who is from Pennsylvania, both my sister and I pick up her friend's accent. When I am with my significant other and his sister at their home for an extended period, I pick up their accents which are southern. My "normal" accent seems to be one that has little accent at all, and I have been told that I seem to have none at all and do not sound at all southern during those times. My sister and I do speak another language to each other regularly and have done so since high school. We are both in our late 40s now and I will be 50 next week. This is an affectation to prevent someone who might overhear us from understanding, and we do not normally speak it with anyone but each other. We both have had extensive French language training, and use it to prevent others from knowing what we are saying if we are being jokingly insulting towards each other, especially silly, or cursing. I am also fascinated by language in general and have attempted to learn and retain more than a couple. I have also in the past, created a language of my own including an accompanying alphabet. I began this project in high school. A friend in high school who was interested in code-breaking attempted to break my "code" and told me at the end of the school year that he was impressed I had created a code he was unable to break. I let him know it was a full language and not a more simple code, and that there were many word and letter combinations that he might have been unable to work out due to the fact that I had specialized symbols that stood for two or more letters (or a specific sound) that were often combined within words. I also currently practice my foreign-language speaking and writing skills often online and on the phone with a friend in Belgium who speaks 4 languages.

comments: I don't really have any to add, other than that a couple of the accents presented here in this study sounded faked or acted. Most sounded authentic, but a few sounded like the person was trying to emulate what they thought a southern or midwestern accent was, not what it actually is.

about: How accent, race, and gender affect our beliefs about their political leanings.
bias or projection of beliefs
assumptions of people based on race and accent
I think this experiment is about how people judge other people based on the accents and perceived beliefs of those people.
comments: I would have liked the option to type my ratings instead of using a slider since I wanted to provide more detailed ratings.
